pros: Health benefits including vision and dental for a very affordable price.
cons: Management/Corporate are slow to react to problems in the work culture, if they ever do at all. They have put more stress on baristas year after year to get work done faster, yet cut labor more, demanding more of each employee with less tools. They want things done the "corporate" way even when it's not the most efficient method. The "customer is always right" mentality leave baristas with little ability to effectively educate customers on the very constraints corporate is putting on us, and instead allows for verbal and psychological harassment from customers to become the norm. Starbucks used to be a great company to work for, the benefits are good but the culture is no longer what it used to be when I started in the 2000's.

review_title: A barista job can be great depending on life stage, but promoting to shift supervisor is not worth it.
pros:
Flexible hours if you remain a barista and do not promote.
Free drink + food item with every shift you work.
Potential for health benefits and more if certain requirements are met.
If you really love Starbucks and are motivated to move up in the company, there are opportunities for you to do so.
Inclusive culture.
cons:
Little to no flexibility for your schedule if you are a shift supervisor.
Difficult to get the time you want off.
Comical raise when promoted to shift supervisor. Not even close to a livable wage.
You are expected to be available at any time, live and breathe all things Starbucks, and get paid barely any additional to barista base pay. This does depend on the state in which you work.

review_title: A love/not so much love relationship
job_title: Shift Supervisor in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: The benefits are amazing, even for part-time employees. It is also definitely a huge perk that you are allowed one free drink and food item per shift. I also really enjoyed being able to work a job where I was allowed to really connect with people and I made a lot of lasting friendships through this job. The training program is awesome, and people from all sorts of industries look highly upon people who have been trained by Starbucks.
cons: I worked in a downtown store, which comes with a lot of issues. We didn't necessarily feel protected by our employer when we experienced things like drug deals, people shooting up in the bathrooms, and sleeping on the tables because of the emphasis on wanting to create a non-discriminatory third place.

review_title: pretty decent for a food job
pros:
- the benefits duh 
- the pay is *close* to what you'd want to make here, the tips are MEH but at least you bank on getting something for them to be honest, even if it's $5 a week
- you can learn a lot about your community through coffee, people can be so friendly and diverse 
- after 6 months you can transfer if you wish to have horizontal mobility/change of scenery
- if you request days off far enough in advance it's easy to be approved
- I think if you dedicate yourself to practicing certain things you'll be surprised at how good you can get
cons:
- managers will schedule you short weird shifts so you only get a 10 min break for 4/5 hours of work 
- super fast paced, only threeish days of training before you're on your own (you can ask for help but still, your coworkers and customers get frustrated when you don't know things) 
- expectations to connect with each individual customer are so high in a super fast paced environment, even in rush hours 
- stores keep closing for 2 weeks at a time due to COVID with NO hazard pay for those scheduled
- for me personally I feel like giving a person two sets of tasks at once is insanity, ie warming food and register, hot bar and cold bar, restocking food and register, etc etc there isn't enough time to do half the things they expect you to do
- EVERY STARBUCKS IS A HIGH VOLUME STORE
